pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:0.5: 6. The training rule on asking non-relations
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.2: At that time Venerable Upananda the Sakyan was skilled at teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.3: On one occasion the son of a prominent merchant approached Upananda, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.4: And Upananda instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.5: Afterwards that merchant’s son said to Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.6: “Venerable, please tell me what you need.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.7: I’m able to give you robes, almsfood, a dwelling, and medicines.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.8: “If you wish to give me something, then give me one of your wrap garments.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.9: “It’s shameful for the son of a good family to walk around in only one wrap.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.10: Please wait until I get back home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.11: I’ll send you this wrap or a better one.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.15: and a third time Upananda said
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.16: the same thing to that merchant’s son,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.17: and he got the same reply.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.18: He then said, “What’s the point of inviting if you don’t want to give?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.19: Being pressured by Upananda, that merchant’s son gave him one of his wraps and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.1: People asked him, “Why are you walking around in only one wrap?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.2: And he told them what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.4: “These Sakyan ascetics have great desires; they are not content.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.5: Even to make them an appropriate offer isn’t easy.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.6: How can they take his wrap when the merchant’s son was making an appropriate offer?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.7: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.8: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.9: “How can Venerable Upananda ask the merchant’s son for a robe?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.10: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.11: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.15: “Foolish man, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.16: And still you asked the merchant’s son for a robe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.17: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.18: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.19.1: ‘If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.20: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.1: At that time, while traveling from Sāketa to Sāvatthī, a number of monks were robbed by bandits.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.2: Knowing that the Buddha had laid down this training rule and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not ask for robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.3: They walked naked to Sāvatthī and bowed down to the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.4: The monks said, “These Ājīvaka ascetics are good people, in that they bow down to the monks.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.6: And the monks said to Venerable Upāli, “Upāli, please examine them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.7: The naked monks then told Upāli what had happened, and he told the monks, “They are monks. Give them robes.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.8: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.10: Shouldn’t they have covered up with grass and leaves?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.11: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.12: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.13: “Monks, if a monk’s robes are stolen or destroyed, I allow him to ask an unrelated householder for robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.14: At the first monastery where he arrives, if the Sangha has a monastery robe, a bedspread, a floor cover, or a mattress cover, he should take that and put it on, thinking, ‘When I get a robe, I’ll return it.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.15: If there’s none of these things, he should cover up with grass and leaves before going on. He should not go on while naked.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.16: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.17: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.18.1: ‘If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.19: These are the appropriate occasions: his robes are stolen or his robes are destroyed.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.6: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.8: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.10: any woman who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.12: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be transferred to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.14: unless it is an appropriate occasion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.16: a monk’s robe is taken by kings, bandits, scoundrels, or anyone whomsoever.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.18: a monk’s robe is burnt by fire, carried away by water, eaten by rats or termites, or worn through use.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.1: If he asks, except on an appropriate occasion, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.2: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.3: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.4: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.5: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.6: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth which I received after asking an unrelated householder, but not on an appropriate occasion, is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.7: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.10: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.1: If the person is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and he asks them for a robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.2: If the person is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he asks them for a robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.3: If the person is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he asks them for a robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.4: If the person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.5: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.6: If the person is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.2: if it is an appropriate occasion;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.4: if he asks those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.5: if he asks for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.6: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.9: The sixth rule, the training rule on asking non-relations, is finished.
